metadata.description: Detailed career progression paths with milestones, timelines, and actionable steps for all career paths in taxonomy

alternative_paths.description: Focus on translating research into commercial products
Lead research teams in academic or government settings

getting_started.education: PhD in relevant scientific field (Chemistry, Biology, Physics, Engineering, etc.) is typically required. Your extensive research background in experimental design, data analysis, and scientific methodology provides the perfect foundation for R&D roles.
preparation_steps: Leverage your doctoral research as proof of innovation capability - frame breakthrough discoveries as 'product development' experience
Translate your lab management skills into industrial R&D language - equipment optimization becomes 'process improvement', protocol development becomes 'methodology design'
Learn industry regulatory frameworks relevant to your field (FDA for biotech, ISO standards for materials science)
Build cross-functional collaboration skills - your experience working with different research groups translates directly to R&D team leadership
Understand intellectual property basics - your publications demonstrate innovation thinking, but learn patent landscape analysis
Connect your research impact to business value - cost savings, efficiency improvements, competitive advantages
Network with industry scientists through professional societies (ACS, AAAS, IEEE) and industry conferences
Consider consulting projects or industry collaborations to gain practical experience before full transition
getting_started.daily_overview: R&D scientists apply the same rigorous experimental methodology you use in academia but focus on developing innovations that solve real-world problems and create commercial value for organizations.
typical_day: Design and execute experiments to test new product concepts or improve existing technologies
Analyze experimental data and interpret results to guide R&D strategy decisions
Collaborate with cross-functional teams including marketing, manufacturing, and regulatory affairs
Present research findings to leadership and recommend next steps for product development
Review scientific literature and patent landscapes to identify innovation opportunities
Write technical reports, patent applications, and regulatory documentation
Manage lab resources, equipment, and junior researchers or technicians
Participate in technology transfer activities and external partnership discussions
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with strong publication record - your research credentials are directly transferable
getting_started.salary_expectations: $75K - $95K for entry-level positions, higher at top pharma/biotech companies with excellent benefits

alternative_paths.description: Lead manufacturing and operations across multiple sites
Focus on quality systems and regulatory compliance

getting_started.education: PhD in Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Biochemistry, or related fields provides excellent foundation for process development careers. Your experience with experimental optimization, scale-up challenges, and analytical method development translates directly to manufacturing process improvement and technology transfer.
preparation_steps: Leverage your experimental design and optimization experience for manufacturing process development - your ability to systematically improve reactions and procedures applies directly to production scale-up
Apply your analytical chemistry and characterization skills to quality control, process monitoring, and method validation
Build on your experience with equipment troubleshooting and method development for manufacturing equipment optimization and process control
Use your project management skills from coordinating research to manage cross-functional process development teams
Learn manufacturing principles including lean manufacturing, statistical process control, and quality management systems
Develop understanding of regulatory requirements for manufacturing including FDA, EMA, and ICH guidelines
Practice presenting process development results to multidisciplinary teams including engineering, quality, and regulatory groups
Network with process development professionals through AIChE, ISPE, and industry conferences

recommended_resources.name: Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA)

getting_started.daily_overview: Process development scientists optimize and scale manufacturing processes from lab to commercial production, using their experimental skills and analytical expertise to improve efficiency, quality, and cost-effectiveness of pharmaceutical and biotechnology manufacturing.
typical_day: Design and execute process optimization experiments - applying your experimental design skills to manufacturing process improvement
Analyze process data and identify opportunities for efficiency and quality improvements
Collaborate with engineering teams to scale laboratory processes to pilot and commercial manufacturing
Troubleshoot manufacturing issues and implement corrective actions using analytical problem-solving skills
Develop and validate analytical methods for process monitoring and quality control
Support technology transfer activities from R&D to manufacturing sites
Write technical reports and present findings to cross-functional teams and regulatory authorities
Manage process development projects with timelines, budgets, and deliverables
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with strong chemistry/engineering background - technical skills are directly transferable
getting_started.salary_expectations: $78K - $100K for entry-level positions, higher at top pharmaceutical and biotech companies

alternative_paths.description: Lead quality and compliance across the organization
Engage with regulatory agencies and policy makers

getting_started.education: PhD in life sciences, chemistry, pharmacy, or related fields provides excellent foundation for regulatory affairs careers. Your research experience with regulatory compliance, documentation, and scientific rigor translates directly to pharmaceutical and medical device regulatory submissions.
preparation_steps: Leverage your experience with research compliance and IRB processes - your knowledge of research ethics and regulatory oversight translates directly to pharmaceutical regulations
Apply your scientific writing and documentation skills to regulatory submission writing and compliance documentation
Build on your experience with FDA regulations from research to understand drug and device approval processes
Use your analytical skills to assess regulatory risks, develop submission strategies, and navigate complex approval pathways
Learn pharmaceutical regulatory frameworks including FDA, EMA, and global regulatory requirements
Develop expertise in Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP), Good Clinical Practices (GCP), and quality systems
Practice presenting scientific data to regulatory audiences using your conference presentation experience
Network with regulatory professionals through RAPS, DIA, and pharmaceutical industry conferences
getting_started.daily_overview: Regulatory affairs specialists ensure pharmaceutical and medical device products meet regulatory requirements for safety and efficacy, using their scientific expertise to navigate complex approval processes and maintain compliance throughout product lifecycles.
typical_day: Review and prepare regulatory submissions including INDs, NDAs, and 510(k)s - applying your scientific writing and analytical skills to regulatory documentation
Analyze regulatory guidelines and requirements to develop submission strategies and compliance plans
Collaborate with cross-functional teams including R&D, clinical, quality, and manufacturing to ensure regulatory alignment
Communicate with regulatory agencies including FDA, EMA, and other global authorities on product approvals
Monitor regulatory changes and assess impact on product development and commercialization strategies
Support clinical trial applications and ensure ongoing compliance with Good Clinical Practices
Review product labeling, marketing materials, and promotional content for regulatory compliance
Provide regulatory guidance to internal teams and support decision-making for product development timelines
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with life sciences background - regulatory knowledge and scientific expertise highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $72K - $92K for entry-level positions, higher at top pharmaceutical and biotech companies

alternative_paths.description: Focus on medical strategy and evidence generation
Transition to regulatory approval and compliance

getting_started.education: PhD/Master's in life sciences (Biology, Chemistry, Medicine, Pharmacy, etc.) provides excellent foundation. Your research experience with protocols, data collection, and ethical considerations directly translates to clinical research oversight.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research protocol experience - translate your experimental design skills into clinical trial protocol understanding
Apply your data collection and analysis expertise to clinical data monitoring and quality assurance
Use your experience with research ethics and IRB processes - this directly translates to clinical research regulatory oversight
Frame your publication experience as evidence of ability to manage complex, multi-site research projects
Learn FDA regulations and ICH-GCP guidelines - build on your existing knowledge of research compliance
Connect your lab management skills to clinical site coordination and vendor oversight
Practice explaining complex research concepts to diverse audiences - essential for investigator training
Join professional organizations like ACRP or DIA to network with clinical research professionals
getting_started.daily_overview: Clinical Research Associates apply the same attention to protocol adherence and data integrity you use in academic research, but focus on ensuring clinical trials meet regulatory standards and protect patient safety.
typical_day: Review clinical trial protocols and monitor site compliance - similar to ensuring experimental protocols are followed in your research
Conduct site visits to assess data quality and protocol adherence - like peer reviewing research methodology and results
Train clinical investigators and site staff on study procedures - leveraging your teaching and mentoring experience
Monitor patient safety data and adverse events - applying your analytical skills to clinical safety assessment
Coordinate with regulatory authorities and internal teams - using your collaborative research experience
Review and verify clinical data for accuracy and completeness - similar to data analysis and peer review processes
Write monitoring reports and communicate findings to study teams - applying your scientific writing and presentation skills
Support regulatory submissions and inspections - using your experience with grant applications and institutional reviews
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 2-6 months for PhDs with life sciences background - your research methodology and regulatory experience are highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $65K - $85K for entry-level positions, higher with PhD and strong research background

alternative_paths.description: Focus on production ML systems and infrastructure
Specialize in product metrics and user behavior

getting_started.education: PhD/Master's in quantitative field (Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Engineering, etc.) provides excellent foundation. Your research background in hypothesis testing, statistical analysis, and complex problem-solving directly translates to data science.
preparation_steps: Leverage your existing statistical knowledge by learning Python/R for data manipulation - your experience with MATLAB/SPSS/SAS gives you a strong foundation
Translate your hypothesis-driven research skills into business problem-solving frameworks
Learn SQL for database queries - similar to querying scientific databases you're familiar with
Apply machine learning to problems in your domain expertise (e.g., image analysis from microscopy â†’ computer vision)
Reframe your research projects as 'data science portfolios' - highlight methodology, insights, and impact rather than just scientific results
Practice explaining complex analyses to non-experts - a key skill you've developed through conference presentations and teaching
Learn business terminology for your analytical skills: 'experimental design' becomes 'A/B testing', 'statistical significance' becomes 'confidence intervals'
Connect with industry professionals through PhD-to-industry networking groups and informational interviews

recommended_resources.name: Python for Data Analysis by Wes McKinney

getting_started.daily_overview: Data scientists apply the same analytical rigor you use in research to solve business challenges - designing experiments (A/B tests), analyzing complex datasets, and communicating findings to drive strategic decisions.
typical_day: Design experiments and analyze results - similar to your research methodology but focused on user behavior or business metrics
Clean and explore datasets - like preparing experimental data but from business systems
Build predictive models using statistical techniques you know (regression, classification) applied to business problems
Create visualizations to communicate insights to stakeholders - like presenting research findings but for business impact
Collaborate with cross-functional teams - your experience working with diverse research collaborators applies directly
Document analysis methods and results - your technical writing skills are highly valued
Stay current with new analytical methods - your ability to learn and apply cutting-edge techniques is a major asset
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs/postdocs with strong quantitative background - your research skills accelerate the transition
getting_started.salary_expectations: $85K - $120K for PhD/postdoc entry-level positions, often 20-40% higher than typical entry-level due to advanced degree

alternative_paths.description: Lead data science and analytics teams across the organization
Focus on developing bioinformatics tools and platforms

getting_started.education: PhD in Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, Computer Science, Biology, or related quantitative fields. Your programming skills, statistical analysis background, and biological knowledge create the perfect foundation for computational biology careers in biotech and pharma.
preparation_steps: Leverage your computational skills for bioinformatics pipeline development - your programming and algorithm experience translates directly to genomics analysis workflows
Apply your statistical analysis expertise to next-generation sequencing data analysis, GWAS studies, and multi-omics integration
Build on your biological knowledge to understand disease mechanisms, drug targets, and precision medicine applications
Practice with public genomics datasets (TCGA, GTEx, gnomAD) to develop portfolio projects demonstrating your analytical capabilities
Learn cloud computing platforms (AWS, Google Cloud) for large-scale genomics data processing and analysis
Develop expertise in bioinformatics tools and workflows (GATK, Bioconductor, Nextflow, Docker) commonly used in industry
Contribute to open-source bioinformatics projects on GitHub to demonstrate your coding skills and collaborative abilities
Network with computational biologists through conferences (ISMB, ASHG, Bio-IT World) and professional societies
getting_started.daily_overview: Bioinformatics scientists apply computational methods and statistical analysis to biological data, combining your programming skills with domain expertise to drive discoveries in genomics, drug development, and precision medicine.
typical_day: Analyze large-scale genomics datasets using statistical and machine learning methods - applying your quantitative analysis skills to biological questions
Develop and optimize bioinformatics pipelines for data processing - leveraging your programming and algorithm development experience
Collaborate with wet-lab scientists to design computational experiments - using your interdisciplinary research collaboration skills
Interpret complex biological data and communicate findings to diverse audiences - applying your scientific presentation and writing experience
Build databases and data visualization tools for scientific teams - combining your technical skills with biological knowledge
Stay current with bioinformatics tools, algorithms, and genomics technologies - similar to following literature in your research field
Participate in cross-functional project teams for drug discovery or diagnostic development
Mentor junior computational biologists and review code for quality assurance
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 2-4 months for PhDs with strong programming background - computational biology skills are in high demand
getting_started.salary_expectations: $85K - $110K for entry-level positions, higher at top biotech/pharma companies with stock options

alternative_paths.description: Lead clinical research and development programs
Focus on commercial medical strategy and market access

getting_started.education: PhD/MD in life sciences, medicine, or related fields required for Medical Science Liaison roles. Your deep scientific expertise, publication record, and ability to engage with key opinion leaders make you an ideal candidate for MSL positions in pharmaceutical and biotech companies.
preparation_steps: Leverage your PhD expertise and publication record to demonstrate deep therapeutic area knowledge - MSL roles require subject matter experts who can engage credibly with leading physicians
Practice translating complex research findings into clinical relevance - your conference presentations and peer interactions prepare you for KOL engagement
Build on your networking skills from academic conferences to develop relationships with key opinion leaders in your therapeutic area
Apply your teaching and mentoring experience to medical education and training activities with healthcare professionals
Learn pharmaceutical industry regulations, compliance requirements, and medical affairs best practices
Develop expertise in evidence-based medicine, health economics, and outcomes research relevant to your field
Practice presenting complex data to diverse medical audiences - your academic presentation skills translate directly to MSL responsibilities
Network with current MSLs through professional societies and LinkedIn groups specific to medical science liaisons
getting_started.daily_overview: Medical Science Liaisons serve as the scientific bridge between pharmaceutical companies and the medical community, using their expertise to provide scientific support, education, and evidence-based information to healthcare professionals and researchers.
typical_day: Conduct scientific presentations and provide medical education to key opinion leaders - leveraging your academic presentation and teaching experience
Engage with healthcare professionals to discuss clinical data and research findings - applying your scientific communication and networking skills
Support clinical research initiatives and investigator-sponsored studies - using your research methodology and protocol development experience
Attend medical conferences and scientific meetings to stay current with therapeutic area developments
Collaborate with internal teams including clinical development, regulatory affairs, and commercial teams
Review and provide scientific input on medical communications materials and educational content
Participate in advisory boards and expert panel discussions with thought leaders in your field
Gather insights from the medical community to inform evidence generation and medical strategy
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with relevant therapeutic area expertise - strong scientific background is highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $130K - $170K for PhD entry-level MSL positions, plus excellent benefits and car allowance

alternative_paths.description: Focus on early-stage technology investment
Lead M&A and strategic investments

getting_started.education: PhD in STEM fields provides excellent foundation for technology transfer careers. Your deep technical expertise, understanding of research commercialization, and experience with intellectual property through publications make you well-suited for university and corporate technology transfer roles.

certifications.name: Association of University Technology Managers (AUTM) Training

preparation_steps: Leverage your research experience to understand technology commercialization - your work on translating research into applications is directly relevant to technology transfer
Learn intellectual property fundamentals including patents, licensing, and freedom-to-operate analysis relevant to your technical area
Develop business acumen around technology valuation, market assessment, and commercial viability analysis
Practice explaining complex technologies to non-technical audiences - essential for engaging with industry partners and investors
Build understanding of startup ecosystems, venture capital, and entrepreneurship through networking and educational programs
Gain experience with contract negotiation, deal structuring, and legal documentation related to technology licensing
Network with technology transfer professionals through AUTM conferences and university technology transfer offices
Consider internships or consulting projects with university tech transfer offices to gain practical experience

recommended_resources.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology Transfer

getting_started.daily_overview: Technology transfer officers bridge the gap between academic research and commercial application, using their technical expertise to evaluate innovations, negotiate licensing deals, and help bring university discoveries to market through industry partnerships.
typical_day: Evaluate new technologies and research discoveries for commercial potential - applying your research evaluation and critical thinking skills
Conduct patent searches and prior art analysis to assess intellectual property landscape
Meet with faculty inventors to understand research applications and commercialization opportunities
Negotiate licensing agreements and partnership deals with industry companies - using communication and analytical skills
Perform market research and competitive analysis for emerging technologies in your domain expertise
Coordinate with patent attorneys, legal teams, and university administration on IP strategy
Develop relationships with industry partners, venture capitalists, and startup companies
Support faculty entrepreneurship and startup formation through university incubator programs
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 4-8 months for PhDs with strong technical background - domain expertise is highly valued in technology transfer
getting_started.salary_expectations: $70K - $95K for entry-level positions, higher at top universities and with industry experience

alternative_paths.description: Become a registered patent attorney
Provide IP consulting to clients

getting_started.education: PhD in STEM fields provides excellent foundation for intellectual property analysis careers. Your deep technical knowledge, research experience, and familiarity with patent literature through academic work make you well-suited for IP roles in law firms, corporations, and government agencies.

certifications.name: USPTO Patent Bar Exam (for Patent Agent status)

preparation_steps: Leverage your publication and patent search experience - your familiarity with scientific literature translates directly to prior art searching and patent landscaping
Apply your technical expertise to understand patent claims and specifications in your domain area - deep technical knowledge is essential for quality IP analysis
Learn patent law fundamentals and IP strategy principles relevant to your technology sector
Practice technical writing for patent applications and IP reports - your scientific writing skills provide excellent foundation
Develop expertise in patent databases, search tools, and analytics platforms used in IP intelligence
Build understanding of competitive landscape analysis and freedom-to-operate studies in your field
Network with IP professionals through conferences, bar associations, and professional societies in your domain
Consider taking the USPTO Patent Bar exam to become a registered patent agent for enhanced career opportunities

recommended_resources.name: United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO)
IP Watchdog - Industry News and Analysis

getting_started.daily_overview: Intellectual property analysts apply their technical expertise to evaluate patents, conduct competitive intelligence, and support IP strategy decisions, using their research skills to analyze technology landscapes and protect innovation assets.
typical_day: Conduct patent searches and prior art analysis using technical databases - applying your literature search and research evaluation skills
Analyze patent claims and technical specifications to assess IP landscape - leveraging your deep technical knowledge and analytical abilities
Prepare technical reports on competitive intelligence and freedom-to-operate analyses
Review and provide technical input on patent applications and prosecution strategies
Collaborate with inventors, attorneys, and business teams on IP strategy decisions
Monitor competitor patent activity and emerging technology trends in your field
Support due diligence activities for licensing deals, acquisitions, and investment decisions
Create patent landscape visualizations and technical presentations for stakeholders
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with strong technical background - domain expertise is highly valued in IP analysis
getting_started.salary_expectations: $75K - $100K for entry-level positions, higher with patent agent status and specialized expertise

alternative_paths.description: Focus on go-to-market and positioning
Lead business units or entire companies

getting_started.education: PhD/Master's in any field provides strong analytical foundation. Your research experience in identifying problems, designing solutions, and managing complex projects directly translates to product management.
preparation_steps: Reframe your research methodology as product discovery - your literature reviews become market research, hypothesis testing becomes user validation
Leverage your presentation skills to communicate product vision - your defense/conference presentations are excellent preparation for stakeholder management
Apply your project management experience from coordinating experiments, managing timelines, and working with collaborators to product development cycles
Translate your domain expertise into product opportunities - many successful PMs come from scientific backgrounds (biotech, healthtech, edtech)
Practice user research methods - your experience interviewing subjects and analyzing behavior applies directly to understanding customer needs
Learn business fundamentals through case studies - treat them like research papers you're analyzing for methodology and outcomes
Build a 'product portfolio' by documenting how your research solved real problems and created impact - emphasize user needs and measurable outcomes
Connect with other PhD-to-PM career changers through networking groups like PhD to PM communities

recommended_resources.name: The Lean Startup by Eric Ries
PhD to Product Manager Career Guide

getting_started.daily_overview: Product managers use the same systematic thinking you apply in research to identify user problems, design solutions, and coordinate teams - essentially running experiments on product features instead of scientific hypotheses.
typical_day: Analyze user data and feedback - similar to analyzing experimental results to understand behavior patterns
Facilitate cross-functional meetings - like coordinating research collaborations across different expertise areas
Conduct user interviews - applying your research interview skills to understand customer needs and pain points
Define product requirements - like writing detailed experimental protocols but for development teams
Prioritize feature development - using the same analytical decision-making you apply to research priorities
Present progress to stakeholders - leveraging your experience presenting research findings to diverse audiences
Research market trends and competitors - applying your literature review skills to business intelligence
Create project timelines and manage deliverables - skills you've honed through managing research projects and deadlines
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-9 months for PhDs with strong communication skills - your analytical background and project management experience are highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $110K - $150K for PhD entry-level positions, often higher due to domain expertise and analytical skills

alternative_paths.description: Lead strategy within corporations
Build own consulting practice

getting_started.education: PhD/Master's in STEM fields highly valued for life sciences and technology consulting. Your analytical thinking, research methodology, and domain expertise in biotech, pharma, or tech industries provide significant competitive advantage in management consulting.
preparation_steps: Leverage your PhD analytical skills for management consulting problem-solving frameworks - your ability to break down complex problems is exactly what consulting requires
Practice case interview methodology using your scientific approach to hypothesis testing and data-driven conclusions
Frame your research experience as 'client advisory' - helping PIs with strategic decisions, optimizing research directions, managing budgets
Develop business acumen in your domain area - life sciences PhDs are particularly valuable for biopharma consulting, tech PhDs for digital transformation
Network with consulting alumni from your university and attend consulting recruiting events - many top firms actively recruit PhDs
Prepare compelling stories about your research impact using business language - cost savings, efficiency improvements, innovation breakthroughs
Practice executive-level communication - your conference presentations and thesis defense experience translates to client presentations
Consider PhD-to-consulting programs at top firms like McKinsey, BCG, Bain, and specialized life sciences consultancies

recommended_resources.name: Case Interview Secrets by Victor Cheng

getting_started.daily_overview: Management consultants apply the same analytical rigor and problem-solving methodology you use in research to help organizations solve complex business challenges, optimize operations, and develop growth strategies - particularly valuable in science and technology sectors.
typical_day: Analyze complex business problems using structured frameworks - similar to developing research hypotheses and experimental design
Conduct data analysis and market research - applying your quantitative analysis skills to business intelligence and competitive analysis
Interview client stakeholders and subject matter experts - leveraging your research interview and collaboration experience
Develop strategic recommendations based on evidence - using the same logical reasoning you apply to research conclusions
Create executive presentations and reports - building on your conference presentation and scientific writing experience
Facilitate client workshops and strategic planning sessions - applying your teaching and mentoring experience to business contexts
Manage project timelines and deliverables - using the same project management skills from coordinating research activities
Collaborate with cross-functional teams - leveraging your experience working with diverse research collaborators and interdisciplinary projects
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 6-12 months preparation for PhD consultants - top firms actively recruit PhDs and value analytical expertise
getting_started.salary_expectations: $130K - $165K for PhD entry-level at top firms, plus performance bonuses and rapid advancement potential

alternative_paths.description: Lead venture investing within large corporations
Focus on later-stage investments and buyouts

getting_started.education: PhD in STEM fields highly valued for venture capital roles, especially in life sciences, deep tech, and emerging technology sectors. Your technical expertise, research evaluation skills, and understanding of innovation cycles provide significant competitive advantage in technology investment analysis.

certifications.name: Private Equity and Venture Capital Specialization

preparation_steps: Leverage your research evaluation skills for technology due diligence - your ability to assess scientific merit and commercial potential is exactly what VCs need for deep tech investments
Apply your analytical methodology to investment thesis development and market analysis in your domain expertise
Build financial modeling skills and understanding of startup valuation, term sheets, and equity structures
Develop network within startup ecosystem through accelerators, incubators, and entrepreneurship programs
Practice presenting investment recommendations and defending analytical conclusions - your thesis defense experience translates well
Learn venture capital fundamentals including fund structure, portfolio construction, and exit strategies
Gain startup experience through consulting, advisory roles, or entrepreneurship to understand operational challenges
Network with VCs through industry conferences, university alumni networks, and professional associations
getting_started.daily_overview: Venture capital analysts evaluate early-stage technology companies for investment potential, using their technical expertise to assess innovation, market opportunity, and founding team capabilities in emerging technology sectors.
typical_day: Evaluate startup pitches and conduct technical due diligence - applying your research assessment skills to evaluate innovation potential and technical feasibility
Analyze market opportunities, competitive landscapes, and technology trends in your domain expertise
Build financial models and investment memos for promising opportunities
Meet with entrepreneurs, founders, and technical teams to assess capabilities and market fit
Support portfolio companies with strategic advice, network introductions, and operational guidance
Attend industry conferences, demo days, and networking events to source new deal flow
Collaborate with investment team on fund strategy, portfolio construction, and exit planning
Research emerging technologies and scientific breakthroughs that could create investment opportunities
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 12-18 months preparation for PhD candidates - combination of technical expertise and financial skills highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $130K - $170K for entry-level positions, plus significant equity upside and performance bonuses

alternative_paths.description: Focus on public engagement and media
Build independent writing practice

getting_started.education: PhD in any scientific field provides excellent foundation. Your dissertation writing, publication experience, and ability to translate complex research into clear communication are exactly what scientific writing requires.
preparation_steps: Leverage your dissertation and publication experience - frame your academic writing as 'medical communication' and 'scientific documentation'
Apply your literature review skills to creating evidence-based content for regulatory submissions and publications
Use your peer review experience to understand quality standards in scientific communication
Practice translating complex research into accessible language - your teaching and conference presentation skills are directly applicable
Learn regulatory writing standards (FDA, EMA guidelines) - build on your knowledge of publication guidelines
Develop expertise in specific therapeutic areas where your research background provides advantage
Build a portfolio of writing samples including different document types (manuscripts, protocols, regulatory documents)
Network with medical writers through AMWA/EMWA local chapters and scientific writing meetups

recommended_resources.name: The Art of Scientific Writing by Hans F. Ebel

getting_started.daily_overview: Scientific writers apply the same attention to accuracy, clarity, and evidence-based communication you use in academic writing, but focus on translating research into documents that support drug development and scientific understanding.
typical_day: Research and synthesize scientific literature - using the same skills you developed for literature reviews and grant applications
Write regulatory documents, clinical study reports, or publication manuscripts - applying your academic writing expertise to industry standards
Collaborate with cross-functional teams to gather information - similar to working with research collaborators and co-authors
Review and edit scientific content for accuracy and clarity - leveraging your peer review and editorial experience
Manage multiple writing projects with tight deadlines - using project management skills from coordinating research activities
Communicate with clients or internal stakeholders about project requirements - applying your grant application and committee interaction experience
Stay current with therapeutic areas and regulatory guidelines - similar to following scientific literature in your field
Mentor junior writers and provide quality assurance - building on your experience training students and postdocs
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 1-3 months for PhDs with strong writing background - your academic writing experience is immediately transferable
getting_started.salary_expectations: $60K - $80K for entry-level positions, higher with specialized therapeutic area expertise

alternative_paths.description: Focus on science journalism and media production
Lead educational institutions and programs

getting_started.education: PhD in any scientific field provides excellent foundation for science communication careers. Your deep subject matter expertise, teaching experience, and ability to translate complex concepts make you well-suited for public engagement, media relations, and educational outreach roles.

certifications.name: National Association of Science Writers (NASW) Training

preparation_steps: Leverage your teaching and presentation experience for public engagement - your ability to explain complex concepts to students translates directly to general audiences
Build on your conference presentation skills to develop compelling science storytelling for diverse audiences
Practice translating your research into accessible language through blog writing, social media, and community presentations
Develop multimedia content creation skills including video, podcasts, and digital storytelling
Learn media relations basics including press release writing, interview techniques, and crisis communication
Build portfolio of science communication work through volunteer opportunities, science festivals, and community outreach
Network with science communicators through professional societies, science museums, and communication conferences
Gain experience with different audiences through schools, libraries, community centers, and public events

recommended_resources.name: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)

getting_started.daily_overview: Science communicators bridge the gap between scientific research and public understanding, using their expertise to create engaging content, develop educational programs, and help society make informed decisions about science and technology.
typical_day: Create engaging content for diverse audiences - applying your teaching skills to develop accessible explanations of complex scientific concepts
Collaborate with researchers to translate findings into public-friendly formats
Develop educational programs and outreach activities for schools, museums, and community organizations
Manage social media channels and digital content platforms to share science stories
Coordinate with media outlets for interviews, articles, and science news coverage
Plan and execute public events including science cafes, festivals, and lecture series
Write grant proposals and reports for science communication funding opportunities
Measure and evaluate the impact of communication programs on public understanding and engagement
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-9 months for PhDs with strong communication skills - teaching and presentation experience highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $45K - $65K for entry-level positions, varies significantly by sector (nonprofit, government, corporate)

alternative_paths.description: Build independent illustration practice
Apply skills to technology and entertainment

getting_started.education: PhD in any scientific field provides excellent foundation for science illustration careers. Your deep understanding of scientific concepts, attention to detail, and ability to visualize complex processes make you well-suited for creating accurate scientific visualizations and educational materials.

certifications.name: Guild of Natural Science Illustrators (GNSI) Certification

preparation_steps: Leverage your scientific knowledge and attention to detail for creating accurate scientific illustrations and visualizations
Build on your experience creating figures for publications and presentations to develop professional illustration skills
Learn digital illustration software including Adobe Creative Suite, Blender, Cinema 4D, and scientific visualization tools
Practice translating complex scientific concepts into clear visual narratives and educational materials
Develop artistic skills through drawing classes, anatomy courses, and visual design training
Build a portfolio showcasing scientific illustrations across different domains and visualization techniques
Network with science illustrators through GNSI, scientific conferences, and online communities
Gain experience with different clients including publishers, museums, educational institutions, and research organizations
getting_started.daily_overview: Science illustrators create accurate visual representations of scientific concepts, research findings, and educational materials, combining their technical knowledge with artistic skills to communicate complex science through compelling visuals.
typical_day: Research scientific concepts and collaborate with researchers to understand visualization requirements
Create detailed scientific illustrations, diagrams, and animations using digital tools and software
Ensure scientific accuracy by consulting with subject matter experts and reviewing scientific literature
Develop visual narratives for publications, educational materials, presentations, and museum exhibits
Iterate on designs based on client feedback and scientific review
Manage multiple illustration projects with varying deadlines and complexity
Stay current with new visualization technologies, software tools, and scientific developments
Collaborate with editors, designers, and educators to integrate illustrations into final products
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 6-18 months for PhDs with artistic interest - scientific knowledge provides significant advantage
getting_started.salary_expectations: $45K - $65K for entry-level positions, higher with specialized expertise and established client base

alternative_paths.description: Focus on product design and visual design
Lead design thinking and innovation consulting

getting_started.education: PhD/Master's in Psychology, Cognitive Science, Human Factors, or any field with strong research methodology provides excellent preparation. Your experience with experimental design and human subjects research is exactly what UX research requires.
preparation_steps: Apply your experimental design skills to user research - your experience with controlled studies translates directly to usability testing and A/B testing
Leverage your qualitative research methods (interviews, observations, ethnography) for user interviews and contextual inquiries
Use your statistical analysis skills for survey design and quantitative user research - the same principles you use for analyzing experimental data
Reframe your research presentations as 'user insights' - your ability to synthesize complex findings for different audiences is highly valued
Build on your experience with human subjects - you already understand ethics, consent, and working with diverse populations
Learn design tools (Figma, Sketch) to communicate research insights visually - treat it like creating scientific figures and diagrams
Connect your domain expertise to UX opportunities - healthcare, education, and scientific software companies value researchers with relevant backgrounds
Join academic-to-industry UX communities and attend UX meetups to understand how research translates to business impact

recommended_resources.name: Observing the User Experience by Kuniavsky
Academic to UX Research Transition Guide

getting_started.daily_overview: UX researchers apply the same rigorous research methodology you use in academia to understand user behavior, test hypotheses about design solutions, and generate insights that drive product decisions.
typical_day: Design and conduct user studies - using the same experimental rigor you apply to academic research but focused on user behavior
Analyze qualitative and quantitative data - applying your statistical skills and thematic analysis experience to user research findings
Create research reports and presentations - leveraging your academic writing and presentation skills to communicate insights to stakeholders
Collaborate with designers and product teams - similar to interdisciplinary research collaborations but focused on product development
Present findings to leadership - using your conference presentation experience to influence business strategy through research insights
Design surveys and interview protocols - applying your research methodology training to understand user needs and behaviors
Review and critique design solutions - using your analytical skills to evaluate whether designs meet user needs based on research evidence
Stay current with UX research methods - similar to following academic literature but focused on applied research in user experience
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 2-6 months for PhDs with strong research backgrounds - your methodology skills and analytical thinking are in high demand
getting_started.salary_expectations: $85K - $110K for PhD entry-level positions, significantly higher due to advanced research skills and methodology expertise

alternative_paths.description: Lead content strategy across organizations
Focus on developer community and experience

getting_started.education: PhD in any field provides excellent foundation for technical writing careers. Your experience writing complex documentation, explaining technical concepts, and creating clear methodological descriptions translates directly to user documentation, API guides, and technical content creation.
preparation_steps: Leverage your academic writing and documentation skills for technical content creation - your experience writing methodology sections and technical papers provides excellent foundation
Apply your ability to explain complex concepts clearly to create user-friendly documentation and tutorials
Build on your experience with various software tools and platforms to document APIs, software, and technical processes
Practice writing for different audiences using your teaching experience - technical writing requires adapting content for various user skill levels
Learn content management systems, documentation tools, and markup languages commonly used in technical writing
Develop expertise in information architecture and user experience principles for documentation design
Build a portfolio of technical writing samples including tutorials, API documentation, and user guides
Network with technical writers through professional organizations and documentation communities

recommended_resources.name: I'd Rather Be Writing - Tom Johnson

getting_started.daily_overview: Technical writers create clear, accessible documentation that helps users understand and use complex technologies, applying their ability to communicate technical concepts to improve user experience and product adoption.
typical_day: Research and understand complex technical products and features - applying your research skills to learn new technologies and software systems
Write user guides, API documentation, and technical tutorials - leveraging your academic writing experience for clear technical communication
Collaborate with developers, product managers, and designers to gather technical information and understand user needs
Edit and review technical content for accuracy, clarity, and accessibility
Design information architecture and content organization for optimal user experience
Test documentation with actual users and iterate based on feedback - similar to validating research methodologies
Maintain documentation standards and style guides for consistency across technical content
Create visual aids, diagrams, and multimedia content to enhance technical explanations
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 2-6 months for PhDs with strong writing background - technical writing skills are immediately transferable
getting_started.salary_expectations: $55K - $75K for entry-level positions, higher in tech companies and with specialized technical expertise

alternative_paths.description: Lead marketing departments and strategy
Build independent creative practice

getting_started.education: PhD in any field provides excellent foundation for science and technology copywriting. Your ability to understand complex concepts, communicate clearly, and write persuasively makes you well-suited for marketing communications in technical industries.
preparation_steps: Leverage your scientific writing skills for marketing communications - your ability to explain complex concepts clearly translates to effective marketing copy
Apply your research and analysis skills to understand target audiences, market positioning, and competitive landscapes
Build on your presentation experience to create compelling marketing narratives and brand storytelling
Use your teaching experience to develop educational content marketing that builds trust and authority
Learn marketing fundamentals including brand positioning, customer journey mapping, and conversion optimization
Develop creative writing skills and understanding of persuasive writing techniques for different audiences
Build a portfolio of marketing copy including website content, email campaigns, social media, and thought leadership articles
Network with marketing professionals through content marketing associations and industry conferences

recommended_resources.name: Science Writers and Communicators of Canada

getting_started.daily_overview: Science and technology copywriters create compelling marketing content that communicates complex technical concepts to diverse audiences, using their scientific background to build credibility and trust in technical marketing campaigns.
typical_day: Research and understand complex technical products and services - applying your research skills to learn new technologies and scientific concepts
Write marketing copy including website content, email campaigns, white papers, and case studies
Collaborate with product managers, scientists, and marketing teams to develop messaging strategies
Create educational content that positions companies as thought leaders in their technical domains
Adapt technical content for different audiences from scientists to C-level executives to general consumers
Analyze marketing performance data and optimize content based on engagement and conversion metrics
Develop brand voice and messaging guidelines that maintain scientific accuracy while being accessible
Support product launches and marketing campaigns with compelling copy that drives customer engagement
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 2-6 months for PhDs with strong writing skills - scientific credibility and communication abilities highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $45K - $65K for entry-level positions, higher in biotech/tech companies and with specialized expertise

alternative_paths.description: Focus on strategic advisory and consulting
Apply market insights to product strategy

getting_started.education: PhD in any field provides excellent foundation for market analysis careers, especially in life sciences and technology sectors. Your research methodology, data analysis skills, and domain expertise make you well-suited for competitive intelligence, market research, and strategic analysis roles.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research methodology and statistical analysis skills for market research design and data interpretation
Apply your literature review and synthesis abilities to competitive intelligence and industry analysis
Build on your experience with data visualization and presentation for market research reporting and stakeholder communication
Use your domain expertise to understand technical markets and translate complex technologies for business audiences
Learn market research techniques including surveys, focus groups, and quantitative analysis methods
Develop expertise in market research tools and databases (IBISWorld, Euromonitor, PitchBook, etc.)
Practice creating compelling presentations and reports for business stakeholders using your academic communication skills
Network with market research professionals through MRA, ESOMAR, and industry-specific analyst communities

recommended_resources.name: European Society for Opinion and Marketing Research (ESOMAR)

getting_started.daily_overview: Market analysts research industry trends, competitive landscapes, and market opportunities, using their analytical skills and domain expertise to provide strategic insights that inform business decisions and investment strategies.
typical_day: Conduct market research and competitive analysis - applying your research methodology to business intelligence and industry trends
Analyze market data, industry reports, and financial information to identify patterns and opportunities
Interview industry experts, customers, and stakeholders to gather market insights
Create detailed reports and presentations on market trends, competitive positioning, and strategic recommendations
Monitor competitor activities, product launches, and industry developments
Collaborate with business development, product management, and strategy teams to support decision-making
Present findings to senior leadership and external clients using your conference presentation experience
Maintain databases of market intelligence and competitive information for ongoing analysis
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with strong analytical background - research and analysis skills are directly transferable
getting_started.salary_expectations: $65K - $85K for entry-level positions, higher with specialized industry expertise and at top consulting firms

alternative_paths.description: Lead sales organizations and revenue generation
Focus on M&A and strategic investments

getting_started.education: PhD in STEM fields provides excellent foundation for business development roles, especially in life sciences, technology, and innovation-driven companies. Your technical expertise, research collaboration experience, and ability to understand complex technologies make you valuable for strategic partnerships and deal-making.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research collaboration experience for business partnership development - your work with multiple institutions and investigators translates to strategic alliance building
Apply your analytical skills to market research, competitive analysis, and opportunity identification
Build on your grant application experience for deal structuring and value proposition development
Practice translating complex technical concepts for business audiences - essential for technology partnerships and licensing deals
Develop understanding of business models, revenue structures, and partnership frameworks in your domain area
Learn sales fundamentals including lead generation, relationship management, and deal closure techniques
Network with business development professionals through industry conferences and professional associations
Gain experience through consulting projects, advisory roles, or internships with startup companies or technology transfer offices
getting_started.daily_overview: Business development managers identify and pursue strategic partnerships, licensing opportunities, and revenue-generating relationships, using their technical expertise to evaluate opportunities and build partnerships that drive organizational growth.
typical_day: Research and identify potential strategic partners and collaboration opportunities - applying your research skills to market intelligence and competitive analysis
Develop and present partnership proposals to internal stakeholders and external partners
Negotiate deal terms, licensing agreements, and strategic alliance structures
Build and maintain relationships with key decision makers at partner organizations
Analyze market trends and competitive landscape to identify new business opportunities
Collaborate with legal, technical, and commercial teams to structure and execute deals
Support due diligence processes for partnerships, acquisitions, and investment opportunities
Track partnership performance and optimize existing relationships for maximum value creation
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 6-12 months for PhDs with strong communication skills - technical expertise and analytical abilities highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $75K - $100K for entry-level positions, often with performance bonuses and equity participation

alternative_paths.description: Become professional investor focusing on startups
Lead innovation within large corporations

getting_started.education: PhD provides exceptional foundation for entrepreneurship, especially in deep tech, biotech, and science-based startups. Your research experience in problem-solving, hypothesis testing, and persistence through uncertainty directly translates to startup challenges and innovation development.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research problem-solving approach for startup challenges - your ability to identify problems, develop hypotheses, and test solutions is core to entrepreneurship
Apply your project management skills from coordinating research to building and managing startup operations
Use your experience with grant applications and funding proposals for investor pitch development and fundraising
Build on your teaching and mentoring experience to develop team leadership and communication skills
Learn business fundamentals including business model development, financial planning, and market validation
Develop technical expertise in your domain into innovative product or service opportunities
Network with entrepreneurs, accelerators, and startup ecosystems through demo days and entrepreneurship programs
Consider starting with consulting or advisory work to build industry connections and validate business ideas

recommended_resources.name: Founder Groups and Local Entrepreneur Meetups
University Technology Transfer and Incubator Programs

getting_started.daily_overview: Entrepreneurs identify market opportunities and build innovative solutions, using their research skills to validate ideas, develop products, and scale businesses that solve real-world problems in their area of expertise.
typical_day: Identify and validate market problems using research methodology - applying your scientific approach to customer discovery and market analysis
Develop innovative solutions based on technical expertise and domain knowledge from your research background
Build and lead cross-functional teams - leveraging your experience managing research collaborations and student mentoring
Pitch to investors and stakeholders using presentation skills developed through conferences and thesis defenses
Iterate on product development using hypothesis-driven testing similar to experimental design
Manage business operations including finance, legal, and strategic planning
Network with customers, partners, and advisors to build business relationships and gather market feedback
Make strategic decisions under uncertainty - a skill well-developed through research experience and problem-solving
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: Variable - can start immediately with idea validation, 6-18 months to launch depending on complexity
getting_started.salary_expectations: Variable - $0 to $100K+ depending on funding, plus significant equity upside potential

alternative_paths.description: Lead business units or entire organizations
Provide operational expertise to clients

getting_started.education: PhD provides excellent foundation for operations management roles, especially in biotech and technology companies. Your project management experience, analytical skills, and ability to optimize complex processes translate directly to operational efficiency and organizational effectiveness.
preparation_steps: Leverage your lab management and research coordination experience for operational process improvement and team management
Apply your analytical and problem-solving skills to identify inefficiencies and develop solutions for business operations
Build on your project management experience from coordinating research activities to manage cross-functional business initiatives
Use your experience training students and managing lab resources to develop team leadership and resource optimization skills
Learn business operations fundamentals including process mapping, workflow optimization, and performance metrics
Develop expertise in operational tools and technologies including project management software, data analytics, and automation platforms
Practice presenting operational analyses and recommendations to stakeholders using your conference presentation experience
Network with operations professionals through industry associations and process improvement communities
getting_started.daily_overview: Operations managers optimize organizational processes and systems to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and support business growth, using analytical skills and project management experience to drive operational excellence.
typical_day: Analyze operational processes and identify improvement opportunities - applying your research methodology to business process evaluation
Coordinate cross-functional projects and initiatives to optimize organizational efficiency
Manage operational teams and resources - leveraging your experience supervising research staff and managing lab operations
Develop and implement process improvements using data-driven decision making and analytical skills
Create operational reports and present findings to leadership teams and stakeholders
Collaborate with different departments to streamline workflows and eliminate inefficiencies
Monitor key performance indicators and operational metrics to track business performance
Support strategic planning initiatives and business scaling efforts through operational expertise
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-9 months for PhDs with strong organizational and project management experience
getting_started.salary_expectations: $55K - $75K for entry-level positions, with significant growth potential and bonus opportunities

alternative_paths.description: Work directly in government agencies
Lead research and policy organizations

getting_started.education: PhD in any scientific field provides excellent foundation for science policy careers. Your deep technical expertise, research methodology, and understanding of how science intersects with society make you well-suited for policy analysis, government relations, and science advocacy roles.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research methodology and analytical skills for policy analysis and evidence-based decision making
Apply your technical expertise to understand complex science policy issues in your domain area
Build on your grant application experience for policy proposal writing and advocacy document development
Use your conference presentation and publication skills for policy briefings and stakeholder communication
Learn government processes, legislative procedures, and regulatory frameworks relevant to science policy
Develop understanding of science funding, research integrity, and technology transfer policies
Practice translating technical research into policy implications and recommendations for non-technical audiences
Network with science policy professionals through AAAS Science & Technology Policy Fellowships and policy organizations

recommended_resources.name: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) Policy

getting_started.daily_overview: Science policy analysts research, analyze, and develop policies that govern scientific research, technology development, and innovation, using their scientific expertise to inform government decisions and shape science funding priorities.
typical_day: Research and analyze complex science policy issues - applying your research methodology to evaluate policy proposals and their scientific implications
Write policy briefs, position papers, and recommendations for policymakers - leveraging your academic writing and publication experience
Engage with scientists, policymakers, and stakeholders to gather input on policy development
Attend congressional hearings, agency meetings, and policy conferences to stay informed on legislative developments
Collaborate with government officials, advocacy organizations, and research institutions on policy initiatives
Review scientific literature and expert testimony to inform evidence-based policy recommendations
Present policy analysis and recommendations to government officials, congressional staff, and advocacy groups
Monitor policy implementation and evaluate the effectiveness of science policies and programs
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 6-12 months for PhDs with policy interest - technical expertise and analytical skills highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $50K - $70K for entry-level positions, higher in federal government and established think tanks

alternative_paths.description: Work on the funding side of nonprofit sector
Build mission-driven businesses

getting_started.education: PhD in any field provides excellent foundation for nonprofit program management. Your research project management experience, analytical skills, and passion for creating societal impact make you well-suited for leading mission-driven organizations and programs.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research project management experience for nonprofit program design and implementation
Apply your grant application and funding experience to nonprofit fundraising and foundation relations
Build on your teaching and mentoring experience to develop community engagement and educational programming
Use your analytical and evaluation skills for program assessment, impact measurement, and data-driven decision making
Learn nonprofit sector fundamentals including board governance, fundraising strategies, and regulatory compliance
Develop expertise in community organizing, stakeholder engagement, and partnership development
Practice translating complex research into accessible language for diverse community audiences
Network with nonprofit professionals through volunteer work, board service, and sector associations
getting_started.daily_overview: Nonprofit program managers design and implement mission-driven programs that address social challenges, using their research and analytical skills to create measurable impact and build sustainable solutions for communities.
typical_day: Design and manage programs that address social or environmental challenges - applying your research methodology to program development and evaluation
Write grant proposals and manage relationships with foundation and government funders
Engage with community stakeholders, beneficiaries, and program participants to understand needs and measure impact
Coordinate with board members, volunteers, and partner organizations to advance mission-driven goals
Analyze program data and evaluate outcomes to demonstrate impact and improve program effectiveness
Manage program budgets, timelines, and deliverables using project management skills from research experience
Advocate for policy changes and systemic solutions based on program insights and community needs
Lead team meetings, strategic planning sessions, and community events to advance organizational mission
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with community engagement experience - analytical skills and mission alignment highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $40K - $55K for entry-level positions, varies significantly by organization size and geographic location

alternative_paths.description: Lead educational institutions
Develop technology for education

getting_started.education: PhD in any scientific field provides excellent foundation for STEM education and outreach careers. Your deep subject matter expertise, teaching experience, and ability to communicate complex concepts make you well-suited for educational program development and community engagement.
preparation_steps: Leverage your teaching and mentoring experience for educational program design and curriculum development
Apply your presentation and communication skills to public engagement and community outreach programming
Build on your experience with diverse audiences from teaching to develop inclusive educational programs
Use your research methodology to design educational assessments and measure program impact
Learn informal education principles including hands-on learning, inquiry-based instruction, and accessible science communication
Develop expertise in educational technology, digital learning platforms, and multimedia content creation
Practice translating complex scientific concepts into age-appropriate and engaging educational content
Network with education professionals through science museums, education conferences, and outreach organizations

recommended_resources.name: National Association for Research in Science Teaching
Center for Advancement of Informal Science Education

getting_started.daily_overview: STEM education and outreach specialists design and implement educational programs that inspire public interest in science, using their expertise to create engaging learning experiences for diverse audiences from K-12 students to adult learners.
typical_day: Design educational programs and curricula that make complex scientific concepts accessible to diverse audiences
Coordinate outreach events including science festivals, school visits, and community workshops
Collaborate with teachers, schools, and community organizations to develop educational partnerships
Create educational materials including lesson plans, activities, and multimedia content
Evaluate program effectiveness and measure educational impact using assessment methods
Train volunteers, educators, and staff to deliver high-quality educational programming
Engage with diverse communities to understand educational needs and develop culturally responsive programming
Manage program logistics including scheduling, budgets, and resource allocation for educational initiatives
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 2-6 months for PhDs with teaching experience - educational background and communication skills highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $40K - $55K for entry-level positions, varies by organization type and geographic location

alternative_paths.description: Lead healthcare organizations and systems
Provide health expertise to organizations

getting_started.education: PhD in public health, epidemiology, biostatistics, or related health/life sciences fields provides excellent foundation. Your research methodology, statistical analysis, and understanding of health systems make you well-suited for population health analysis and public health program evaluation.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research methodology and statistical analysis skills for epidemiological studies and health data analysis
Apply your experience with large datasets and statistical software to health surveillance and population health research
Build on your knowledge of research ethics and human subjects to understand public health ethics and community engagement
Use your analytical skills to evaluate public health interventions and assess program effectiveness
Learn public health frameworks including social determinants of health, health equity, and population health management
Develop expertise in health policy analysis, health economics, and healthcare systems
Practice communicating research findings to public health practitioners, policymakers, and community stakeholders
Network with public health professionals through APHA, state health departments, and public health organizations

recommended_resources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Association of Schools and Programs of Public Health
National Association of County and City Health Officials
Public Health Jobs and Career Resources

getting_started.daily_overview: Public health analysts use epidemiological methods and statistical analysis to monitor population health, evaluate public health programs, and inform evidence-based policies that improve community health outcomes.
typical_day: Analyze health surveillance data and identify disease patterns, outbreaks, and health trends in populations
Conduct epidemiological studies to investigate health problems and evaluate intervention effectiveness
Collaborate with public health practitioners, healthcare providers, and community organizations on health initiatives
Prepare reports and presentations for health departments, policymakers, and community stakeholders
Support public health emergency preparedness and response activities using data analysis and modeling
Evaluate public health programs and policies to assess impact on population health outcomes
Engage with communities to understand health needs and develop culturally appropriate public health interventions
Stay current with public health research, emerging health threats, and evidence-based public health practices
getting_started.timeline_to_entry: 3-6 months for PhDs with quantitative health research background - analytical skills and health knowledge highly valued
getting_started.salary_expectations: $50K - $65K for entry-level positions, higher in federal agencies and large health departments

alternative_paths.description: Transition to university-based research
Move into government or policy roles

getting_started.education: PhD in any field provides excellent foundation for NGO and think tank research careers. Your research methodology, analytical skills, and academic writing experience translate directly to policy research, advocacy, and thought leadership in mission-driven organizations.
preparation_steps: Leverage your research expertise and analytical skills for policy research and evidence-based advocacy work
Apply your academic writing and publication experience to policy briefs, research reports, and thought leadership content
Build on your grant application experience for nonprofit fundraising and foundation relations
Use your conference presentation skills for stakeholder engagement, media relations, and policy advocacy
Learn nonprofit sector dynamics including funding models, advocacy strategies, and coalition building
Develop expertise in policy analysis frameworks, impact measurement, and strategic communications
Practice translating complex research into accessible policy recommendations for diverse audiences
Network with NGO professionals through volunteer work, policy conferences, and issue-based organizations

recommended_resources.name: Center for Strategic and International Studies

getting_started.daily_overview: NGO and think tank researchers conduct independent research on social, economic, and policy issues, using their academic expertise to generate evidence-based insights that inform public policy and advance organizational missions.
typical_day: Conduct independent research on policy issues using rigorous academic methodology and analytical approaches
Write research reports, policy briefs, and thought leadership pieces for diverse audiences including policymakers and media
Engage with stakeholders including government officials, advocacy organizations, and community groups
Present research findings at conferences, briefings, and public events using your academic presentation experience
Collaborate with interdisciplinary teams on complex research projects addressing social and policy challenges
Secure research funding through grant applications to foundations, government agencies, and international organizations
Monitor policy developments and emerging issues relevant to organizational mission and research agenda
Participate in media interviews, congressional briefings, and expert panels to share research insights
